She has had  training in entrepreneurship and small business management from Youth Self Emloyment Foundation (YOSEFO). Happy has a plan to expand her business.She needs to add two sewing machines,employ one more assistant and increase the stock of sewing materials.This business expansion will help her increase income thus meet the needs of her family including school fees for her children.

loans.use: Purchasing sewing materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his weighing equipment maintenance business

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr:
Born in 1983 in Tsevie, Mr. K. B. Kossi is a qualified mechanic and also produces items to sell. Single and without any children, he is nevertheless responsable for the care of his parents and two yonger school aged brothers. Very dynamic and technical in his preofession, he has sucessfully repayed his previous loans without any problems.

In oder to open other stores where he can sell his products and to purchase new work tools, he is asking for a loan of $1,200.00, which he will use to rent a boutique and to purchase wrenches. With this loan, he will be able to increase his earnings and to better contribute to the improvement of the living conditions of his family.

Translated from French by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Né en 1983 à Tsévié, Monsieur K. B. Kossi est un mécanicien qualifié qui fabrique aussi des pièces pour vendre. Célibataire sans enfant, il a néanmoins à sa charge ses parents et deux petits frères scolarisé. Très dynamique et technique dans son métier, il a su gérer les crédits obtenus et les a remboursé sans incident. Ainsi pour pouvoir ouvrir d’autres magasins de vente de pièces fabriquées et acheter d’autres instruments de travail, il sollicite un crédit de $1200 qui servira à louer une boutique et acheter des clés de travail. Ainsi il pourra augmenter ses chiffres d’affaires et contribuer efficacement à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: To rent a boutique and to purchase working materials.

loans.name: Bushra

texts.en:
"I have four children and none of them is able to obtain an education because of our financial problems. Some years back my husband and son started their own furniture business in a rented shop, which has not proven to be a sufficient mode of income. We think that by buying a shop and investing in the raw materials for our business we can be successful. For this, we need $295 so that we can invest in and expand our business."

Bushra A., Pakistan

loans.use: To purchase a shop and raw materials for our Furniture Business

loans.name: Misirkhan

texts.en: Misirkhan H. lives in the Ashigli village of Beylagan, a small city in south-western Azerbaijan. He is 58 years old, and married with 5 children. Misirkhan established his sheep-breeding business 15 years ago. He needs $800 to buy 10 sheep and expand his business.

loans.use: To buy 10 sheep

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 27 years old he is married and has 2 children, one of whom is going to school. His mother and father are living with him. He has a snack shop in Kirkuk. He has applied to get $1000 to purchase a new ice box and new goods, and expand his project by renovating the shop, painting it, and hiring one unemployed person to help him in the shop to increase his income.

This entrepreneur is from a volatile region, and this loan may present a higher repayment risk. Lenders should be aware of this fact when deciding to lend.

To protect the identity of this entrepreneur, their name has been modified and their image in the photograph has been obscured.

loans.use: Purchase new ice box and new goods

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
Gregoria lives in the region of San Martín in the province of Mariscal Cáceres in the district of Juanjui. She sells food at the port in the region as well as at her house. She also sells plantains and firewood. She has always liked to work and needed a loan to start a small business, thanks to the invitation to join the Communal Bank "El Tiempo es Oro" (Time is Gold). Thanks to the loan she received from Manuela Ramos, she has been able to contribute to her home and help her husband.

With this loan of 800 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy items for the kitchen such as rice, sugar, oil, red and white meat, potatoes, and noodles. She will also buy half a load of firewood, which she will sell in thirds, three bunches of plantains, and other items. Gregoria has three people in her home who are retired and who she takes care of after she comes home from selling her food at the port of Amberes.

Gregoria is 61-years-old, and she has five independent children. She lives with her husband who has shared her life for 40 years and who lives with her sorrows, joys, and pains. Both plan to save a little money so they can enjoy a peaceful old age.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Gregoria vive en la región San Martín, provincia D. Mariscal Cáceres, distrito D. Juanjui. La señora Gregoria se dedica a la venta D. comida en el puerto D. la zona y en su casa, además venD. plátanos y leña. Siempre le ha gustado trabajar y necesitaba un préstamo para emprender un pequeño negocio, gracias a la invitación para ingresar al Banco Comunal “El Tiempo es Oro” y al préstamo recibido por Manuela Ramos ha podido contribuir y apoyar a su esposo en el hogar.

Con el préstamo D. S/.800.00, el cual pagará en 06 meses, comprará artículos para la cocina como arroz, azúcar en kilos, aceite en botellas, carnes rojas y blancas, papas y fideos en kilos, también comprará media carga D. leña D. los cuales venderá en tercios, también comprará diez racimos D. plátanos y otros. La señora Gregoria cuenta con tres personas que reciben pensión en su casa a los que atienD. después D. regresar D. realizar su venta en el puerto Amberes.

La señora Gregoria tiene 61 años, cinco hijos independientes y vive con su esposo con quien comparte su vida desD. hace 40 años y con quien vive sus penas, alegrías y dolores, ambos piensan ahorrar un poco y poder pasar una vejez tranquila.

loans.use: Purchase of materials for her kitchen (rice, sugar, oil, red meat, etc.)

loans.name: Nancy's Group

texts.en:
Haydee, Obdulia and Nancy have belonged to the community bank “Cusi Urpi”, which means "happy bird" in Quechua, for one year, four months, and three years respectively. In their community bank they have learned to save, to be responsible, how to run their business, family planning techniques, and how to avoid getting sick.

Haydee is 19 years old and is single. She sells ceviche, a traditional dish made from marinating fish in lemon juice, near the college. She has had this business for two years. Haydee would like to improve her business by adding more tables. In addition, she would like to buy a cement mixer, which she could then rent out. At the same time she is studying to be able to enter the University.

Obdulia is a single mother. She is 43 years old and has two children. Obdulia sells food staples such as flour and sugar from a stand in the April Market of Ayacuhco. Furthermore, Obdulia has a small piece of land outside of town where she grows alfalfa to also sell in the market.

Nancy is 28 years old and single. She sells cosmetics from a catalogue to her family and friends. Nancy is thinking of opening a salon.

Haydee, Obdulia and Nancy need loans of 400, 200, and 600 soles (3 soles =$1), which will be invested in buying alfalfa seeds, sugar, rice, paying their laborer, tables, fish, and to open a salon. The community bank emphasizes the importance of saving, and each associate has an interest earning savings account. They are saving to buy a cement mixer, to pay for medical care for their daughter, and to open a beauty salon. Their dreams are to own a solid home, be professionals, that their children will be professionals, and to open their own salon.

loans.use: Haydee, Obdulia and Nancy need loans of 400, 200, and 600 soles (3 soles =$1), which will be invested in buying alfalfa seeds, sugar, rice, paying their laborer, tables, fish, and to open a salon.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema is 56 years old and a resident of the Tandika area in Dar Es Salaam city. She runs a small restaurant at her home, a business which she has had for the past ten years. She is in need of a loan to to help her expand her business

loans.use: Expand her cafe business

loans.name: El Rosario Nahuala Group

texts.es:
Ten minutes before the ”Rosario Nahuala” embroidery group begins, one can see groups of women, in typical dress, running through the streets of Nahuala shouting the names of their friends in the native Quiche language. What is happening is that the members of the group are looking for their friends who are not present in the Friendship Bridge office for the payment. Until all the clients of the communal bank are present, the loan cannot be repaid. For many of the clients, the repayment of the loan is one of the most important events of the month.

The meeting begins five minutes late, but with all members of the group in the office. Many are a little anxious but happy to receive their first loan. Others reflect the shyness typical of new clients. This shyness will fade away in time, as the group consolidates and they all receive training about self-esteem and women’s rights, among other themes of interest.

All the clients work in the textile industry. The majority work in traditional fabrics. Meanwhile others embroider flowers and birds in the typical blouses of the region. Finally, the rest of the group buys and sells clothes and traditional dress. They are going to use the loan to buy the thread and clothes of their respective resale.

It is believed that once the clients start to receive a loan their opportunities and dreams will begin to flourish. The women would like to learn about administration of their business. By luck, Friendship Bridge offers training in the themes in which the clients have interest. This basic training helps the women very much, especially those who are new to microfinance.

Surprisingly, the common dream among everyone is that their respective business can grow so that they can support and send their children to school. It is in our hands to support these women with their noble goals. Few people spend so much effort for the benefit of others. It is an admirable characteristic that people worldwide should imitate, and with our help these women can realize their dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Katrina H, Kiva volunteer.

Diez minutos antes de empezar la reunión de desembolso del grupo “el Rosario Nahuala” uno podía ver grupos de señoras, en sus trajes típicos, corriendo por las calles de Nahuala gritando los nombres de sus compañeras en el idioma Quiché. Lo que pasaba era que las integrantes del grupo estaban buscando a sus compañeras que no estaban presentes en la oficina de Friendship Bridge para el desembolso, y hasta que no estén todas las clientas del banco comunal el préstamo no se puede desembolsar. Para muchas de las clientas el desembolso del préstamo es uno de los acontecimientos más importantes del mes.

La reunión empezó cinco minutos tarde, pero ya con todas las integrantes del grupo en la oficina. Muchas de ellas estaban un poco ansiosas pero felices por ¡recibir su primer préstamo! Otras, reflejaban aquella timidez típica de clientes nuevas. Esa timidez se va borrando a través del tiempo conforme el grupo se vaya consolidando y ellas vayan a recibiendo capacitaciones sobre autoestima y derechos de la mujer entre otros temas de su interés.

Todas las clientas trabajan en la industria textil. La mayoría trabaja en tejidos tradicionales. Mientras que otras bordan flores y aves en las blusas típicas de la región. Finalmente, el resto del grupo compra y vende ropa y trajes tradicionales. Ellas van a utilizar su préstamo para la compra de hilo y ropa para su respectiva reventa.

Se cree que una vez las clientas empiezan a recibir préstamos sus horizontes y sueños empiezan a agrandarse. A las señoras les gustaría aprender más sobre administración de sus negocios y medicinas. Por suerte, Friendship Bridge ofrece capacitaciones en los temas que las clientas están interesadas. Este tipo de capacitaciones básica ayuda mucho a las mujeres, especialmente a las que recién empiezan en las microfinanzas.

Sorprendentemente, el sueño común de todas es que su respectivo negocio pueda crecer para que así puedan alimentar y mandar a sus hijos al colegio. Está en nuestras manos apoyar a estas señoras con sus nobles metas. Pocas personas avocan todos sus esfuerzos para el beneficios de otros. Esto es una característica intachable de la cual muchas personas en el mundo deberían de imitar y solo con su apoyo estas señoras van a poder cumplir sus sueños.

loans.use:
Purchase of thread for embroidery of typical blouses

Compra de hilo para bordados en blusas típicas

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina is 21 years old and is a married woman with 1 child, age 1 year old. Paulina owns a small stock of chickens, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works from 6 am to 10 pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $55 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more chickens to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy more chicken to increase her stock.

loans.name: Marco Martin

texts.es:
Currently the client lives in a single room that he shares with his wife and daughter. He gives private tennis lessons. He will use the loan to buy a piece of land since in the future he wants to have his own house and be able to provide his family with a better home.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer.

EL cliente actualmente vive en una habitación que comparte con su esposa e hija, trabaja dando clases particulares de ténis, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de un lote de terreno ya que en el fututo desea tener su casa propia y poderle brindar mejores condiciones de vivienda a su familia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land.

loans.name: Ines Veronica

texts.es:
Ines Veronica P. is a woman who has worked for many years operating her own general store in her native town of Chinandega.

It is important to highlight that thanks to the support offered from Ceprodel, she has improved her business substantially, adding new display counters and shelves where she can place her products. Now she is again seeking a loan from Ceprodel in order to purchase more merchandise for her business. She has previously repaid two loans from Ceprodel and has stood out for her faithful, on-time payments.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer.

Ines Veronica P. es una dama que desde hace varios años se dedica a atender su propia pulpería en la ciudad de Chinandega de donde es originaria.

Es de mucha importancia destacar que gracias al apoyo brindado por Ceprodel, ha logrado mejorar las condiciones de su negocio habiendo adquirido vitrinas y nuevos estantes donde colocar sus productos. Hoy en día una vez mas busca el apoyo en Ceprodel para obtener el crédito para la compra de mercadería en su negocio. Su record crediticio es de 2 créditos con la institución habiéndose destacado como fiel cliente en su record de pagos.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Sarum

texts.en:
Mr. Sarum K. (shown in the picture with his mother), 32, and his wife, who live on an island in the MeK. River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 2000 and have two daughters. Sarum is living with his mother who is a silk weaver.

Since he was married, Mr. Sarum has been a silk weaver, a skill he learned from his mother, and his wife is a silk weaver as well. The couple sells their finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh.

He is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase silk materials for his weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Latifa

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Latifa R. was born thirty-five years ago; she's married with two children, ages 10 and 16. In 2005, Latifa established her poultry business (kuku) which enables her to earn a monthly profit of 500 USD. Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Who or what are "kuku," you may ask. Kuku means "chickens" in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. They require little start-up capital: you can start with two and wait for them to multiply naturally! They also require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Latifa is requesting the loan of 875 USD in order to purchase 400 chicks and additional feed. In the future, Latifa plans to buy even more chicks and expand her business further!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy additional chicks and feed for her poultry business.

loans.name: Aida

texts.fr: Aida N. est une femme agée de 59 ans .elle est mariée et habite au quartier Cité Lamy de thiès .elle fait du commerce de denrées alimentaires  et quelque fois des tissus depuis vingt ans elle sollicite ce pret pour le renforcement de ses activités.
texts.en:
Aida N., 59, is married and lives in the Cité Lamy neighborhood in Thiès. She has been selling foodstuffs and sometimes cloth for 20 years. She is asking for this loan to bolster her little businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: sale of foodstuffs

loans.name: Naima's Group

texts.en: Naima has had a genge stand in Zanzibar for two years. A genge stand sells fruits and vegetables. They vary in size and can be as small as just a wooden plank with a handful of tomatoes or as large as a platform with a huge variety of fruits and vegetables. She currently earns approximately $60 each month from her genge stand. She is single and has no children. Naima will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Mariam. Mariam also has a shop in Zanzibar.  Both women are hoping that this loan allows them to expand their businesses and increase their profits.

loans.use: Naima would like to purchase more vegetables for her shop and Mariam would like to improve her business.

loans.name: Ilda Carolina

texts.pt:
Ilda Carolina M. é natural de Manhiça um distrito nortenho da província do Maputo, tem 44 anos de idade, casada maritalmente e mãe de 4 filhos com idades entre 26, 22, 20 e 15 anos respectivamente, para alem dos filhos sustenta uma neta que vive com ela.

Ilda estudou ate 6ªclasse e não continuou por falta de condições,   Ilda vive basicamente de negocio, onde  destaque  a Cerveja que compra por 250,00mt a caixa e vende por 360,00mt, refrescos  que adquira a caixa por 148,00mt e vende por 240,00mt. Tem um rendimento mensal de 8000,00mt e consegue poupar mensalmente 4000,00mt.

Para Ilda este é o seu primeiro empréstimo na Hluvuku e no Kiva e pretende pagar antes do tempo para solicitar outro afim de abrir outro tipo de negocio que consistira na venda de produtos de mercearia.
texts.en:
Ilda Carolina M. is from Manhiça, a northern district of Maputo province. She is 44 years old, married, and mother of four children, aged 26, 22, 20, and 15. Besides her children, she supports a granddaughter that lives with her. Ilda studied until sixth grade and didn't continue, because of lack of finances. Ilda basically lives off her business. She sells beer, which she buys at 250 meticais per case and sells for 360 meticais, and soft drinks, which she buys at 148 meticais and sells for 240. She has a monthly income of 8000 meticais, of which she manages to save 4000 monthly. For Ilda, this is her first loan from Hluvuku and Kiva, and she plans to pay it off in advance in order to make another loan with the intention of opening another type of business, a general store.

Translated from Portuguese by Ilse Ackerman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of soft drinks

loans.name: John

texts.en: John K. N. is a 56-year-old trader; he is married and has four children. Two children have completed senior high school. He is a very resourceful husband and father whose hard work brings livelihood to the family. John K. supports his wife and household through the sale of used clothing in Kantamato market in Accra. Selling used clothing is a very big market in Ghana because brand new clothes are very expensive for the economically-active poor. Selling used clothing has created a big market for many men and women. John K. requests a loan to buy more bales of used clothing and shoes to increase his inventory. He believes this loan would help him save for his children’s future education and also to rent a store in which to trade.  John K. is a member of the group called Macedonia. The members agree to serve as guarantees for each other to repay the loans. John K. said he would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: Buy more bales of used clothing and shoes

loans.name: Dora

texts.es:
La señora Dora es socia del Banco Comunal “Wiñay” del distrito de Puno, provincia de Puno, en el departamento de Puno. Tiene 58 años de edad, es casada y madre de 2 hijos a los que apoya económicamente. Dora con el primer préstamo de S/ 300 compró mercadería para venderla en su tienda. Tiene casi 3 años trabajando con el banco. 
Con este préstamo de S/. 1500 que pagaré en 4 cuotas comprará más mercadería para ser vendida en su tienda de abarrotes.
Dora desea continuar trabajando para apoyar a su familia.
texts.en:
Dora is a member of the communal bank "Winay", in the district and province of Puno. She is 58 years old and married with 2 children whom she helps support financially. With her first loan, Dora purchased merchandise to sell in her small general store. She has been working with the communal bank for almost 3 years now. With the new loan, which she will repay in 4 payments, she will purchase more merchandise for her business so that she can continue to support her family.


Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for her small general store

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en: Sunday O. is 49 years old and married with 5 children. He sells books. He loves this business and hopes to expand his business. He needs the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more books to sell. He says thanks to all who made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more books to sell

loans.name: Erdene

texts.en:
Erdene N. is a 40-year-old man who lives with his wife and four children. He has two sons and two daughters. His sons, aged 16 and 18, are going to high school. One of his daughters is 12 years old and goes to elementary school. His other daughter is 13-years-old and handicapped, therefore homebound for many years.

Erdene's wife makes the traditional Mongolian "deel" -- a type of silken robe worn by women and men -- as well as vests, which he then sells. During the Lunar New Year, many people wear "deel" and traditional vests. She gets many orders for sewing "deel" every year before the Lunar New Year. Right now, she doesn't have money to buy materials; therefore she's been making deals with her clients to provide her materials. However, from this year on, they are planning to take a loan to buy their own materials for "deel" and traditional vests.

Erdene will sell "deel" and the traditional vests that his wife sews at a higher price. Erdene said: "My children are growing well now. We had really hard times when my children were young, between the ages of 1 and 6. What I and my wife are most worried about is our handicapped daughter's future. We are working hard even now to make her future better."

loans.use: To buy silk for making Mongolian traditional robes called "deel"

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila P. is 52 years old and a married mother of three children. She lives in Poblacion, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store and sells fish. Her husband is a fisherman and Mila sells the fish that he catches in the neighborhood and in nearby villages. Two of her children are in college and one is in high school. 

She started her business by applying a loan from loan sharks (5-6) who charged her a high interest payments. Currently, the store and fish vending operations are stable, but due to the increasing cost of school for her children, she needs to expand her business to generate more income. She needs a loan of of PHP 5,000 to purchase groceries to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI.

loans.use: To purchase groceries to sell

loans.name: Benedicta

texts.es:
La señora Benedicta C.  vive en casa de sus padres, en la zona  de Llojeta, ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz, con su esposo, el señor Prudencio Jiménez y sus tres hijos.
La señora Benedicta trabaja como educadora en un Centro Comunal de su zona y su esposo trabaja en una fábrica de papel de la ciudad de El Alto adyacente a nuestra ciudad. 
El crédito es para la realización de piso de cemento en la habitación que ocupa ya que la misma solo tiene piso de tierra.
Esta es la segunda vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado la califican favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito
texts.en:
Señora Benedicta C. lives in the home of her parents in the zone called Llojeta, on the west side of the city of La Paz, with her husband, Señor Prudencio Jiménez, and their three children. Señora Benedicta works as an educator in the Community Center of the zone, and her husband works in a paper factory in the city of El Alto, adjacent to their own city. The loan is to make a cement floor in the home they occupy that currently only has an earthen floor. This is the second time that she has asked for a loan, and the socioeconomic analysis shows that she is well qualified and able to accept the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To construct a cement floor for Benedicta's home

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda H. is 46 years old and married with five children. As a mother, all she wants is to see all her five children finish their studies. She supports her husband through her small business selling used clothing (ukay-ukay). There is a great demand for this item but Rosalinda needs more capital to purchase large supplies of used clothing.

Therefore, Rosalinda wants to avail a loan from HSPFI in the amount of PHP 7,000 to cater the needs of her established customers and to her local market.

loans.use: To purchase used clothing (ukay-ukay) for sale.

location.town: Purok 9, Kiwalan, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Carren

texts.en:
Carren W. is the 36-year-old mother of two children, ages 14 and 12. She is married to a coordinator in Migori. She runs a small business selling bags, second-hand bags, and shoes in Kibuye market, Kisumu's largest open-air market. She lives on the outskirts of Nylanda Slum close to Dunga Beach. She wants to increase her stock and is asking for 10,000 KSH. She says she averages around between 6,000-10,000 KSH in profit a month (about $125 USD) and says she likes running her own business because she never goes without money.

Carren recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin-enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: Bags, Shoes for re-sale

loans.name: Zikra

texts.fr:
Madame  Zikra  M. est âgée de 53 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants, elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants dans le quartier Missira dans la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
N’ayant pas été à  l’école pour des considérations sociales, parents très religieux qui voyaient en l’école des blancs, une porte de déperdition. Dès sa tendre enfance elle s’adonna au petit commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait du riz. Riche d’une solide expérience acquise au chevet de sa mère, après son mariage elle décida d’évoluer de ses propres ailes  en menant depuis 20 ans le commerce d’articles divers (thermos, cartes prépayées, tasses, chaussures, téléphones portables etc.) et jouit  d’une grande notoriété. 
C’est dans le souci d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, qu’elle a fait recours à  Soro Yiriwaso depuis 30 mois. Après 1 prêt individuel et 3 prêts solidaires tous bien remboursés, elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel qui  sera utilisé pour acheter, 50 thermos, 10 paires de chaussures, 3 douzaines de tasses, 10 téléphones portables et un carton de cartes prépayées de l’opérateur téléphonique Orange. Elle s’approvisionne  en cartes de recharge et téléphones portables à Bamako, en thermos, tasses et chaussures au Ghana. Elle vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle à domicile et en ambulant à une clientèle composée majoritairement d’hommes.   
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 70 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour épargner, acheter des animaux petit à petit et rembourser le prêt. 
Son ambition est d’épargner le plus que possible afin de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Zikra M. is 53, married and the mother of 5 children. She lives with her husband and children in the Missira neighborhod of the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Never having attended school because of socio-economic reasons, she had very religious parents who saw the "white man's school" as the road to perdition. Since she was very young, she busied herself with petty trading, working with her mother who sold rice. Rich in experience gained at her mother's side, she decided after her marriage to go out on her own and has been in business for 20 years, selling various items (thermos bottles, prepaid phone cards, dishes, shoes, portable phones, etc.) and has a very good reputation.

It is with the intention of increasing her working capital that she joined Soro Yiriwaso, 30 months ago. After 1 individual loan and 3 solidarity loans, all correctly reimbursed, she is on her second individual loan which will be used to buy 50 thermos bottles, 10 pairs of shoes, 3 dozen bowls, 10 portable phones, and a carton of prepaid phone cards from "Orange" cell telephone server. She buys her telephones and rechargeable cards in Bamako; her thermos bottles, bowls and shoes come from Ghana. She sells for cash and credit, out of her home and door-to-door, to a clientele composed primarily of men. She expects to make an average monthly profit of 70,000 F CFA which will be used to add to her savings, buy some animals little by little, and reimburse the loan.

Her ambition is to save as much as possible so as to build a house to live in.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Emilio

texts.en:
Emilio O. is from the town of Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City. He is 54 years old. Emilio is married and has 9 adult children. To make a living, Emilio owns & operates a business financing mining activities through purchasing gold dust from miners and selling it with mark-up to the local jewelers. Emilio has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Emilio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to engage in business activities. Emilio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Emilio is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to be used as capital to finance the mining activities. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Emilio from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support needs of relatives and other family members. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To finance the mining activities.

location.town: Pigsag-an, Cagayan De Oro City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Gulguncha

texts.ru: Гулгунча Махмадова проживает в Яванском районе. Возраст 35 лет. Замужем, детей не имеет. Гулгунча более 4 лет занимается пашивом одежды, этой услугой она занимается у себя дома. Муж предоставляет услугу такси. Клиентка просит кредит для расширения деятельности.
texts.en:
Gulguncha M. lives in the Yavan region. She is 35 years old. She is married and does not have children. Gulguncha has been sewing clothing for more than four years, she provides these services at home. Her husband works as a taxi driver. The client is asking for a loan to expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To expand business

loans.name: Trương's Group

texts.en:
Toàn Trương Thị is a 38-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Toàn is the group leader of a seven-member group through SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual L., they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Đồng Thôn 02.


Toàn is married and has two school-aged children.  To make a living, Toàn owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community.  Toàn has been engaged in this business for more than five years and earns approximately 4,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


Toàn joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Toàn is requesting  a L. from SEDA for the first time.  She is requesting a L. of 5,152,000 VND, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering.  Toàn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Cao Thị Cừ is a 49-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND L. to support her business making and selling food.


2.  Nguyễn Thị Ngũ is a 38-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND L. to support her service-based business.


3.  Trương Thị Thọ is a 50-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND L. to support her business raising livestock.


4.  Nguyễn Thị L. is a 25-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND L. to support her service-based business.


5.  Nguyễn Thị Hoà is a 35-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND L. to support her business raising livestock.


6.  Phạm Thị Quế is a 33-year-old female who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND L. to support her business raising livestock.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this L. was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Toàn Trương Thị  là 38 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Toàn là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 7 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Đồng Thôn 02 (2).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các mặt hàng nhu yếu phẩm như dầu gội đầu, xà bông & kem đánh răng trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Toàn thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Toàn kiếm được khoảng 4.000.000 VND.  Toàn đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Toàn đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ SEDA.    Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Cao Thị Cừ  là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


2.  Nguyễn Thị Ngũ là 38 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


3.  Trương Thị Thọ là 50 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Nguyễn Thị L.  là 25 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


5.  Nguyễn Thị Hoà  là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


6.  Phạm Thị Quế  là 33 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Bertha Leonor

texts.es: La señora Bertha Leonor tiene la edad de 34 años, casada y con un hijo estudiante de la primaria, reside en el barrio Memorial Sandino, su esposo se desempeña como Mecánico Automotriz, su negocio es la venta de productos nutricionales, inicio con la necesidad de apoyar  a su esposo con los gastos ya que todo esta caro y poder cumplir con las metas en terminar de construir su casa ya que es muy pequeña donde habita y quiere hacer un anexo para poder tener comodidad. Da las gracias Afodenic por el apoyo con el préstamo ya que a través de ello ha logrado hacer las mejoras a su vivienda.
texts.en:
Señora Bertha Leonor is 34 years old, married and has a son who is a student in grade school. She resides in the neighborhood of Memorial Sandino. Her husband works as an Automobile Mechanic. Her business is the sale of nutritious products. She begin her business because of the need to support her husband with the expenses, since everything is so expensive. She also wanted to achieve their goal of finishing the building of their house, since the place they live is very small and she wants to add an annex to be able to have more comfort. She gives thanks to Afodenic for the support of the loan since through it she has managed to do the improvements to her dwelling.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy building materials to build an addition to her house

loans.name: Latt

texts.en: Mrs. Latt K. is a farmer in Kouk Doung village in Takeo province. She owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn for living. In this plantation, she has a problem because her field is infertile which it is a bad to affect to her crop. Thus, she decided to request for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field. Her husband, Mr. Ank Oeurn, owns an electric cow which been hired by the villagers to plow on the field and to transport the rice. This couple has four children who are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To request for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field.

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en: Iyabo sells kitchen utensils. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is 38years old and married with 4 children. She has been in the business for years. She is requesting for the loan amount of N60, 000 to purchase more kitchen utensils to sells. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kitchen utensils

loans.name: Mavzuna

texts.en:
Mavzuna K. is 25 years old. She runs a beauty salon, providing services such as hair cutting and styling, manicures, and cosmetology.  The salon also rents wedding dresses and national dresses. The salon is rather successful and generates a stable income for the family. Mavzuna would like to purchase new wedding and national dresses for renting and therefore requests a loan of $3000. Mavzuna thanks everyone who supports her and promises to repay the loan promptly.  

More about Tajikistan:
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.  But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's history:
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase wedding and national dresses for rental.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: acheter des noix de palme

loans.name: Annet's Group

texts.en: N. Annet is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is 32 years old and married with 4 children.  She also takes care of other dependents. Annet is a determined and hard working businesswoman with a salon in Rwanyamuzira that she has been running for 8 years. She is able to make 150,000 shillings in profits a month, and she would like this to increase in the future. Annet says that her good customer care skills, in addition to the loans that help her restock, have helped her a great deal in growing her business. She dreams of expanding it further, and of having a stable family. Annet needs a loan to help buy more salon equipment like a drier, combs, hair extensions and chemicals.  These products will help her to provide quality services.

loans.use: to purchase salon equipment

loans.name: Marifel

texts.en: Marifel A. is from the village of Libertad Alto, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old, is married, and has seven school-aged children. Marifel owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-one years and earns approximately 2,400 PHP a month. In 2005, Marifel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to pay for services to increase crop yield. Marifel is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be her 10th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Abdufatto

texts.en:
Abdufatto B. is 65 years old and lives with his wife and two children. He is a hard-working person, which he demonstrates each and every day as he carries out the arduous tasks of living in the countryside. Abdufatto has been a farmer from the start, having inherited his lands – and the occupation – from his parents. With the passing of time, he has also implemented raising livestock into his enterprise. Each day, he takes his cows to graze in the far reaches of his fields. With these activities, he earns income to support the living expenses of his family. Abdufatto is learning every day how to run his business to the best end result. He seeks a loan for working capital, specifically so he can buy cattle, considering that the prices for them are low now. Abdufatto deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Daakubulee Group

texts.en:
Lorpu Tokpah is a leader of a group of 4 borrowers, called Daakubulee. She is single with 2 children, aged 8 and 10 years old, who are in kindergarten and 1st grade. Lorpu is an illiterate due to the lack of financial support. She lives and works in the Belefania community, Gbarnga city, the capital of Bong county, Liberia.

Her business is the sale of prepared food. She cooks food that is sold per plate to residents of her community in Gbarnga. Lorpu has been running this business for 3 years, and hopes to improve her business. Lorpu faces problems with the long distance required to get materials to prepare the food to serve to her clients. Her food is always tasty and clean, in order to encourage customers to continue buying her food. Lorpu needs this loan to purchase more materials for cooking. She dreams of giving her family the best help she can to improve their lives.

loans.use: To purchase more materials for cooking.

loans.name: Dayse Paola

texts.es:
Dayse Rodríguez de 32 años, tiene una casa de cemento ubicada en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, Dayse empezó comprando una pequeña lavadora para su familia pero como una y otra vecina le pedía lavar sus ropas decidió comprar otra lavadora y así entre mas le pedían mas lavadoras compraba con esto ella comenzó el alquiler de lavadoras. 

Ahora Dayse tiene 15 lavadoras en las que las alquila a $ 15.00 la hora, una de las mayores complicaciones es el continuo desgaste de las piezas, esta en unión libre con su pareja en la que el le ayuda con los gastos haciendo fletes en su carro, ellos tienen 1 hijo que estudia en una escuela fiscal.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar $ 300.00 en piezas de lavadoras, para construir mejor el lugar de las lavadora también quiere comprar materiales de construcción $ 500.00, mano de obra $ 200. En el futuro quiere ampliar más su lavandería y poder construir más su casa.
texts.en:
Dayse Rodríguez, 32 years old, has a cement house located in the perimeter of Guayaquil. Dayse started by buying a small washing mashine for her family, but since some of her neighboors started asking to do their laundry there, she decided to buy another one. Then, the more people asked for the laundry, the more machines she bought and that was how she started to rent washing machines.

Now Dayse has 15 washing machines, which she rents by $15 per hour. One of the biggest challenges is the continuing wearing of the machines' parts. She lives in a common law marriage and her partner helps with the expenses by doing freights with his car. They have one child, who studies in a public school.

With this loan she wants to buy $ 300.00 of washing machines parts and, in order to improve the machines location, she wants to buy construction materials with $500.00, plus $200 for the labor. In the future, she wants to expand her laundry business and her house.

Translated from Spanish by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cement, stones, labor

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia B. is from the village of San Fermin, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is forty-eight years old. Cecilia is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Cecilia owns and operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing party services to local community members. Cecilia earns approximately 500 PHP daily for these activities.

In 2009, Cecilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecilia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the third loan Cecilia has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Kasenge Kiguli Group, Mpigi

texts.en: N. Florence is the leader of her lending group in Mpigi. She is a hard-working and sociable lady with a business dealing in agricultural produce growing and selling produce in the markets in Kampala for 6 years. She is able to make 100,000/= as profit each week. Florence is married with 7 children all in school, and she hopes to educate all her children to the highest level as well as continuing to grow her business.

loans.use: Buying more agricultural produce for resale

loans.name: Ivania Vaneska

texts.es: La joven Ivania tiene la edad de 28 años,  ha sido una mujer esforzada, para salir adelante en sus estudios, es casada, y tiene una niña de un año de edad, que cuida su mama,  su esposo trabaja como cobrador en la empresa Café Soluble. Ella trabaja en un banco desempeñándose como cajera, tiene un año laborando a la institución pero su salario es bajo y trabaja hasta los fines de semana en los comerciales nuevo en la capital en donde gana esas extras, lo cual abecés no logra estar mas tiempo con su familia y la otra dificultad es que sale muy tarde y va con miedo en la ruta por la delincuencia que asecha.  Sus planes es lograr un asenso y poder obtener otro puesto que le genere ganar mejor para poder lograr terminar de hacer las mejoras a su pequeña casa que junto con su esposo han logrado construir, este préstamo lo solicito por que tiene la necesidad de poder hacer el baño y  no cuenta con el dinero en efectivo, para la obra es por eso solicito Afodenic quien esta dando la oportunidad para que realice estas mejora. Lo cual estoy contenta por hacer el baño para una mejor privacidad y higiene en mi casa. Para esto comprara materiales de construcción como: piedra, arena, cemento, hierro para y piso para comenzar la obra.
texts.en:
Ivania is 28 years old and has worked hard to get ahead in her studies. She is married and has a one year old daughter, who her mother helps care for. Her husband works as a collector for the Café Soluble plant. She works as a teller in a bank. She has been doing this for one year, but her salary is low. She also works with the new businesses in the capital city on the weekends, where she can earn a little extra, but this limits the time she is able to spend with her family. She also gets off of work very late and she is often afraid when traveling home, because of the crime along her route. Her plans are to move into another position that will provide better income, which will allow her to complete the improvements to her small home, which she and her husband have managed to build. She requested this loan because she needs to complete her bathroom and she doesn’t have the money for the labor. This is why she reached out to Afodenic, who is providing the opportunity to make these improvements. “I am happy to be able to complete the bathroom in order to have better privacy and a more hygienic home.” She has already purchased building materials, such as stone, sand, cement, iron, and flooring to begin the work.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo R., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building materials and lobor

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 27 years old and married with one child who is in school. He has been running a retail shop for three years. He previously worked in the industrial area but now he earns extra living as a barber. Since he became a member of Faulu Kenya, he has learnt how to save his money. He describes himself as hardworking and hopes to open other branches in the future.

John has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy sugar (for 5,000 KES), flour (for 10,000 KES) and cooking fat (for 5,000 KES).

loans.use: To add stock

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en: Sandra sells bags of cement retail. Demand for her bags of cement is high and she hopes to be able to meet it. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is 35 years old, married with four children who attend a public school in Ughelli, Delta State. She hopes for a loan of N80,000 to buy more bags of cement to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of cement to sell

loans.name: Nelly's Group

texts.en:
Nelly Y. is from the village of Brgy. Sta. Cruz, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 44 years old. Nelly is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Nelly is married and has four school-aged children. Nelly owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Nelly has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 4000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2007, Nelly joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from ASKI, which was for 8000 PHP and which was used purchase additional products to sell.

Nelly is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to purchase new items to further expand her product offerings.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand store inventory

loans.name: Mirian Clara

texts.es:
La Señora Miran Clara M. Ocampo de 32 años de edad trabaja como comerciante,(vendedora de remedios medicinales), variedades de productos los vende por varias zonas(Villarrica, san Juan Nepomuceno, Caazapa y otros).
 El mismo trabaja con su cónyuge el señor,. Ovidio Duarte también comerciante el mismo va y comercializa los remedios, de casa en casa; ya sobre pedidos.
Ella primero recorre los negocios de varias la zona  como Independencia, Caazapa, Villarrica etc., para las solicitudes de pedidos y luego llevan los productos directamente a los negocios.
Con miras a mejorar el estilo de trabajo y de esa forma poder obtener mayor ganancia solicita el préstamos a la Fundación Paraguaya para la compra de una moto ya que de esa forma podrán movilizarse bien para los pedidos y entrega de productos(remedios naturales medicinales).
Agradece por la ayuda recibida ya que su deseo es de seguir trabajando y prosperar con su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mirian Clara M. Ocampo is 32 years old. She sells a variety of medicinal products in Villarrica, San Juan Nepomuceno, Caazapa, and other districts. Her husband, Mr. Ovidio Duarte, also helps with the business. He markets the products and takes orders door to door. She goes to businesses in Independencia, Caazapa, Villarrica, as well as other districts. She takes the orders and delivers them in person. With the goal of improving the way she conducts business and earning a higher profit, she has asked Fundación Paraguaya for a loan to buy a motorcycle. With the motorcycle, she and her husband will be able to take orders for the medicinal products and deliver them more efficiently. She is grateful for the help. Her goal is to continue working and get ahead for the benefit of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Montserrat Zuckerman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Léa

texts.fr: Née en 1978 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, F. Léa est mariée à KOBITI Martial, un mécanicien. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont trois sont à leur charge. Léa vit avec ses enfants et son mari à Fifadji, un quartier de Cotonou. C’est depuis huit ans que Léa s’est installée dans ce quartier. Léa vient en aide à son mari en ce qui concerne les différentes charges de la famille. Léa n’a jamais été à l’école. Il y a près de quatre ans que Léa a commencé la vente de maïs et d’huile d’arachide dans son quartier. Léa s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Léa a déjà bénéficié de deux prêts de ALIDé et qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Léa sollicite un autre crédit, en vue d’augmenter son stock de produits et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1978 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Léa F. is married to Martial Kobiti, a mechanic. The couple have four children, all in school, of whom three are in their care. Léa lives with her husband and children in Fifadji, an area of Cotonou. It has been eight years since Léa began living in this area. Léa helps her husband in meeting the various needs of the family. Léa never went to school. About four years ago, Léa begin selling maize and peanut oil in her area. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Léa has already benefited from two loans through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners) and repaid both of them properly. Faced with the increasing demand of her customers, Léa is seeking another loan, with the goal of increasing her stock of products and better satisfying her clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of maize and cans of peanut oil

loans.name: Julia Victoria

texts.es:
Julia se dedica al trabajo de cerámica hace 15 años juntamente con su esposo, con mucho esfuerzo pudo conseguir clientes que obtengan sus productos como son
Bebederos y comederos para animales. El préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de productos que necesita para su trabajo. Nuestra socia está agradece el préstamo y se compromete a  hacer sus respectivos pagos en las fechas según su cronograma. seeks to use micro-credit to foster productive commercial activity for the sake of economic and social development within vulnerable urban and rural sectors traditionally neglected by commercial banks. By offering innovative products such as technical education loans and microfinance groups for young persons, EDAPROSPO helps disadvantaged Peruvians lift themselves out of poverty.
texts.en:
Julia has been working with pottery alongside her husband for 15 years. Through great effort she has gained customers for items such as feed and water troughs for animals. She will invest the loan in items she needs for her work. Our partner is grateful for the loan and commits herself to making payments on the dates listed in her repayment schedule. EDAPROSPO seeks to use micro-credit to foster productive commercial activity for the sake of economic and social development within vulnerable urban and rural sectors traditionally neglected by commercial banks. By offering innovative products such as technical education loans and microfinance groups for young persons, EDAPROSPO helps disadvantaged Peruvians lift themselves out of poverty.

Translated from Spanish by Solson Scherman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies for her business

loans.name: Sophy

texts.en:
Mr. Sophy P. is 40 years old and lives in Khpob Kraom village, Kandal province. He is a farmer who owns 1 hectare of land to cultivate rice Aside from being a farmer, he also breeds pigs.  With both businesses, he earns a small income, enough to support his family.  His wife, Channary Ear, is a teacher at the local school where she earns a small salary and with her husband income they are able to meet their family living expenses. This couple has three children, who all are students. The children help support their father businesses. Channary Ear is in the picture with him.

To improve his pig breeding business, Sophy P. decided to ask for a loan to buy additional supplies of pig feed.

loans.use: To buy supplies of pig feed

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma B. is from the village of Benhaan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 34 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Emma owns & operates a retail trading business.  The main source of income for her business is buying raw green bananas and other crops like copra and sweet potato from neighboring villages and selling them to the local community. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more crops to sell. This will be Emma's 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more crops to sell

loans.name: Maria Lastenia

texts.es:
La Señora María Lastenia es socia del banco comunal Nueva Juventud, vive por la parroquia de Tarqui, esta parroquia es la mayor productora de leche ya que su gente en su mayor parte se dedica a la ganadería y a la agricultura, mucha de su población ha emigrado a varios lugares del mundo en busca de una mejor calidad de vida para sus familias.

Nuestra socia  tiene de 40 años de edad,  es casada y tiene 3 hijos quienes se encuentran de 20, 18, 6 años de edad, sus dos primeros hijos trabajan y le ayudan económicamente, su esposo no tiene un trabajo estable y solo labora cuando le contratan para alguna construcción ya que es maestro albañil, con el esfuerzo  conyugal han logrado construir su casa propia.

La Señora. María se dedica a los quehaceres de su hogar, también a la cría de pollos, cuyes, chanchos y ganado los mismos que los vende cuando tiene alguna necesidad.

 La señora es nuestra socia hace dos ciclos y está  muy contenta con sus amigas del grupo,  su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de abono para el potrero y así criar y tener alimento para su ganado, ya que su meta es  seguir creciendo en su negocio.
texts.en:
Maria Lastenia is a member of the Nueva Juventud community bank and lives near the parish of Tarqui. This parish produces large quantities of milk since the majority of the population works in agriculture and raising cattle. Much of the population has emigrated to various places around the world in search of a better quality of life for their families. Our partner is 40 years old, married with 3 children ages 20, 18 and 6. Her two older children work and help economically while her husband can't find steady work, but does so when he is hired as a master bricklayer. Their joint efforts have allowed them to build their own home. Maria takes care of the daily household chores as well as raising chickens, guinea pigs, pigs and cattle which she sells when the need arises. She has been our partner through two cycles and is very happy with her friends in the group. Her new loan will be invested in the purchase of fertilizer for the grazing field so she can feed her cattle properly since her goal is to keep growing the business.

Translated from Spanish by Solson Scherman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase Fertilizer

loans.name: Yuliya

texts.en:
Yuliya is married. She runs a small business selling fish and sea products at one of the open markets in Berdyansk town. Yuliya has been in this business for six years. Her products are always fresh and a good quality, which is why Yuliya has many regular clients who buy from her. She enjoys her business and wants to develop it further.

Yuliya would like to borrow 8,000 UAH to purchase more inventory for her business. She hopes to receive additional income and improve her business conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie M. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is 48 years old. Tessie is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Tessie owns & operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Tessie says she works hard so she could help provide food for her family and proper education for her children. She hopes to have all her children finish college someday and hopefully for them to have a bright future.

Tessie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This will be the second loan taken out by Tessie from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and to improve their living conditions. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies & equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Mr. Pen S. earns his living and is highly skilled at building stone houses. He goes to work from construction site to construction site around his community, earning $6 per day. He is a single man and he resides with his elderly widowed mother who helps to arrange a daily routine. Pen S. says that he currently pays much money to hire a taxi to travel to his work location. He would like to have his own vehicle, which would allow him to commute to work without hiring a taxi. As he doesn’t have money yet to buy one, Pen S. is applying for a loan in order to buy a secondhand motorcycle.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorcycle to commute to his job sites

loans.name: Djémila

texts.fr: Y. est une jeune femme célibataire, pour subvenir à ses propres besoins, elle s'est lancé dans la vente de bazins, elle a commencé ce commerce depuis 1995.  elle s'approvisionne à Lomé et commande aussi son stock au mali. actuellement elle fait face à une baisse de son stock de marchandises. elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat d'une vingtaine de bazins.
texts.en:
Y. is a young single woman who has sold bazins (local cloth) for a living since 1995. She sources her goods from Lomé and orders her goods from Mali. She is currently facing a stock shortage and so is seeking a loan from WAGES to purchase around twenty bazins.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of bazins (fabric)

loans.name: Juana De La Cruz

texts.es: Juana D. La Cruz R. D. S. D. 41 años D. edad,  resiD. en Soyapango, lugar en el cual vive junto a su esposo y sus cuatro hijos, todos menores D. edad, quienes se dedican a estudiar. Juana posee una pupusería la cual se encuentra en su casa D. habitación y en donD. trabaja desD. hace 8 años con el único fin D. poder contar con una vida mejor para su familia. Ella solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda invertir en el negocio comprando toda la materia prima para la elaboración D. las pupusas, tales como: chicharrón, queso, frijoles, maíz, y verduras para hacer el curtido y la salsa que acompaña a las pupusas. D. esta manera Juana desea atender a más clientes y D. esta forma mejorar sus ventas.
texts.en: Juana D. La Cruz R. D. S. is 41 years old. She is a resident of Soyapango, where she lives with her husband and her four children, who are not yet grown and are attending school. Juana has a pupusería [a business making pupusas, or filled corn tortillas] located in the house where she lives. She has run this business for 8 years, with the single aim of achieving a better life for her family. She is requesting a loan so that she can invest in her business by purchasing all of the ingredients needed to prepare pupusas, such as: pork, cheese, beans, corn and vegetables to make the curtido [a slaw-like salad] and salsa which accompany the pupusas. In this way, Juana wants to serve more customers and thus improve her sales.

loans.use: Buying cheese, corn, beans and pork

loans.name: Akakpo

texts.fr: amétoehoun est une femme de 36 ans très dynamique, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de détail de maïs et d'huile. elle a commencé ce commerce en 2009; voulant agrandir son activité, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat de 5 sacs de maïs et 6 bidons d'huile végétale. sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes.
texts.en: Amétoehoun A. is a very dynamic 36 year-old woman. Her line of business is the retail sale of corn and oil. She started this business in 2009.   As she now wants to expand her business, she is seeking a loan from WAGES to buy 5 bags of maize and 6 drums of vegetable oil. Her clients include all types of people.

loans.use: Purchase of corn and oil

loans.name: Juan Vicente

texts.es:
Juan de 57 años, elabora muñecos de porcelana y los vende a las tienda, vive en una zona periurbana con todos los servicios básicos el lugar está ubicado en la Perimetral de Guayaquil zona rodeada de un estero.  

Juan elabora muñecos de porcelana con cerámica en polvo el proceso es sencillo primero mescla con algunos adictivos y hace una masa y la coloca en moldes especiales con formas de muñecos, después los mete al horno con una temperatura de 60º cent, los deja enfriar y les comienza hacer la imagen con pintura. Comienza hacer los muñecos desde las 08h00am y en la tarde los vende en el centro de la ciudad. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar materiales como adictivos, cerámica en polvo para hacer mas muñecos y tener mayores ingresos. En el futuro quiere tener el negocio en su casa y tener una consultoría dental para su hija mayor.
texts.en:
57-year-old Juan makes porcelain figurines and sells them to stores. He lives in a peri-urban area with all the basic services that is located in the Perimetral de Guayaquil area, surrounded by a marsh.

Juan makes porcelain figurines with ceramic powder. The process is simple. First, he mixes in some additives and makes a mass. Then he puts it in special molds in the form of figurines. Afterwards, he puts them in a kiln heated to 60 degrees centigrade. He lets them cool and then begins painting their faces. He starts making the figurines at 8am and in the afternoon sells them in the center of the city. 

With the loan, he wants to buy materials such as additives and ceramic powder to make more figurines and have greater income. In the future he wants to operate the business out of his home and have a dental clinic for his oldest daughter.

loans.use: To buy additives and ceramic powder

loans.name: Nora

texts.en: Nora A.  is 25 years old, married, and has two children, both of whom attend school.  She is currently in the business of selling fish, ground nuts, and simsim at the market.  She is requesting a loan to stock bags of ground nuts and simsim to sell.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up store for her goods.

loans.use: To stock bags of ground nuts and simsim to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more cartons of fish

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn A. is from the village of Tumbao, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 42 years old. Jocelyn is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods and snack foods in the local community.
